docs.lead_paragraph: American International Group and the United Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that they had formed a joint venture that would offer health care services in selected Asian countries. American International Group and United Healthcare will each have a 50 percent stake in the new company, AIG United Healthcare. The joint venture's first health care services organization has been established in Hong Kong and expects to begin enrolling members in the first quarter.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: David Gollaher (Op-Ed, Jan. 7) overestimates the impact on individuals and insurers of genetic discrimination laws. New state laws concerning health insurance only prohibit genetic discrimination against people who are asymptomatic. Once they begin to exhibit symptoms of disease, the insurer is generally free to cancel the policy or to increase rates to unaffordable levels. Mr. Gollaher also fails to note that different incentives and policy issues are implicated by the results of different genetic tests (for example, degree and severity of risk) and the different social contexts in which they may be used (health versus life insurance).

headline.main: For Some, Human Cloning Might Offer Hope; Insurers' Prerogative

docs.abstract: Mark A Rothstein letter contends that David Gollaher Jan 7 Op-Ed article overestimates impact on individuals and insurers of genetic discrimination laws

docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal appeals court ruled last week that the General Motors Corporation had the right to change or end lifetime health benefits that 84,000 workers contend the company promised them before they retired. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit here rejected the retirees' contentions that the auto maker broke its promise to provide them with free lifetime health care benefits.

headline.main: Court Backs G.M. On Retirees' Benefits

docs.abstract: Federal appeals court ruled last week that General Motors Corp had right to change or end lifetime health benefits that 84,000 workers contend company promised before they retired; salaried employees who retired from GM between 1974 and 1988 sued in 1989, accusing GM of violating terms of its health care plan and Federal regulations (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: David Gollaher (Op-Ed, Jan. 7) asks us to value the health of the insurance company over the health of the consumer. He even compares insurance consumers who keep genetic information private to ''inside traders.'' Yet the extremely profitable insurance industry holds most of the cards when it comes to deciding who can be covered at what cost. Moreover, he fails to point out that having a genetic predisposition to a condition does not mean that an individual will develop that condition. But knowing the risk of genetic discrimination may have the adverse effect of keeping an individual from learning his or her genetic information in order to make better medical decisions.

headline.main: For Some, Human Cloning Might Offer Hope; Genetic Privacy, Please

docs.lead_paragraph: First it was ice, then a paralyzing darkness when power lines fell and the lights blinked out. Now weary residents of Eastern Canada, already reeling from the most damaging winter storm in memory, are shivering under a dangerous cold spell. At least 15 people have died since the storm began to lash the area on Jan. 5. The police are now going door to door in some places warning residents, particularly the elderly, that they should move to community shelters as temperatures dip within a few degrees of zero.

headline.main: Freeze Grips Canada, Already Iced and Powerless

docs.abstract: Weary residents of Eastern Canada, already reeling from most damaging winter storm in memory, are shivering under dangerous cold spell as temperatures dip within few degrees of zero; at least 15 people have died since storm began on January 5, and 590,000 residents of Montreal and outlying areas remain without electric power; utility officials say it will take up to two weeks to restore service to all customers, 1.4 million of whom were affected at peak of storm; more than 10,000 people are living in 120 temporary shelters in Montreal, and other shelters have been set up in outlying areas and in parts of eastern Ontario that were hit hard by storm authorities say is one of most damaging ever to strike Canada; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Robert L. Birnbaum (letter, Jan. 8) suggests that even for managed care, ''the marketplace will eventually provide good value to consumers.'' His examples of McDonald's, MCI and Southwest Airlines are fine if the discussion is limited to customers who not only can choose among health care providers but also can choose to decline the service altogether. Further, my choice of hamburger, dial tone or airline is normally not life-threatening or irreversible.
docs.abstract: Kenneth G Rubsam letter disputes Robert L Birnbaum's January 8 letter on managed care (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health spending increased in 1996 at the lowest rate in 36 years, but topped $1 trillion for the first time, the Government reported today. Such spending has been growing at the same pace as the economy for four years in a row, contrary to earlier projections, which showed health care eating up a bigger and bigger share of the nation's output. Even so, consumers did not see more money in their pockets, because many employers shifted costs to their workers.

headline.main: Health Spending Grew Slowly in '96 but Still Hit $1 Trillion

docs.lead_paragraph: THE two questions I was asked most often in 1997 were ''Is that dietary supplement still helping your arthritic knees?'' and ''Are there results yet from the studies being done on this side of the Atlantic?'' Fourteen months ago, following my arthritic spaniel's dramatic improvement upon taking a supplement containing two substances that play a role in the formation of cartilage, glucosamine and chondroitin sulfate, I decided to try the stuff myself. Two months later, ignoring bemused queries like ''Are you barking yet?'' I reported about a 30 percent improvement -- not an absence of pain and stiffness, but less of them and little or no swelling after activities like tennis and ice skating that gave my knees a workout.

headline.main: The Arthritis Is at Bay, Thank You

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column reports improvements in her arthritic knees after 14 months of taking dietary supplement containing glucosamine and chondroitin sulfate; diagrams illustrate how exercises with squeeze ball can strengthen arthritic hands (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Paradox of Genetic Privacy'' (Op-Ed, Jan. 7): David Gollaher says that part of the problem posed by genetic testing is ''how to make health insurance more secure and prevalent.'' But that statement rings hollow in the context of his argument that the private insurance industry should be free to use information about an individual's genetic makeup.

headline.main: Market Failure on Health Insurance; Regulate the Industry

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about increases in premiums for health maintenance organizations in the New York region misstated the amount paid by one patient, Linda Gibbs, to Oxford Health Plans. Her premium is $216 monthly, not $311.
